instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00923: What is 820-00923? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.3V3_G3H: What is 3V3_G3H? This is one of the first power rails that must turn on for Macbooks that use USB-C for charging. This power rail powers the CD3215 chip that controls the USB-C charger, speaks to the USB-C charger, and requests 20 volts up from the default 5 volts that the USB-C charger puts out when initially connected to an unknown device. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-05 No Power
threads.message:
Hi Guys.

i have a board 820-923-05 not powering on took some measurements shorted on <CAPACITOR>C3200</CAPACITOR> and <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> is only 5v. Any suggestions please?

Thanks :cool:

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-05 No Power
threads.message:
Do you mean <CAPACITOR>C3200</CAPACITOR> was shorted and changed?
Or you still have a short on <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> rail?

All 4 USB-C ports show same voltage/current?
Check diode mode to ground on all CD3215s power rails.
<CHIP>U3200</CHIP> could be the affected one.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-05 No Power
threads.message: Thanks 2Informaticos, still waiting from the client to approve the repair and in the meantime i ordered type C controllers just in case i need them just couldn't find a stencil. Will update asap... :D
